node.title: Does Australia need an 'anti-scam centre' to fight phone scammers? Labor thinks so
node.description: Labor wants to target social media companies profiting from scammers and establish a national anti-scam centre, as part of a proposed crackdown on dangerous and annoying calls from fraudsters.
node.content:
["What seems like an age ago, the sound of a ringing phone inspired\u00a0warm feelings at the thought of a friend or family member on the other end of the line.", "These days, the buzzing in your bag or pocket mostly just inspires annoyance and an eye roll\u00a0as you see a unknown number flash up on the screen.", "The rate of scam phone calls has exploded during the pandemic, with criminals seeking to exploit vulnerable and isolated people, often using fake parcel delivery notifications\u00a0or threatening calls from supposed government agencies.", "Scammers stole $851 million from Australians last year, a record amount according to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.", "The number of phishing scams \u2014\u00a0where\u00a0an official-looking message from a seemingly trustworthy source\u00a0is used to steal financial information \u2014\u00a0has risen by 75 per cent during\u00a0the pandemic.", "
Labor wants 'scambusters' centre, crackdown on social media companies
", "In response to record fraud, the federal opposition is proposing a national anti-scam centre to combat what it calls a \"scamdemic\" of online and phone fraudsters.", "Stephen Jones, the Shadow Minister for Financial Services, said\u00a0bringing law enforcement, banks, social media and telecommunications companies under the same tent would allow them to quickly spot and block scammers.", "\"People are sick and tired of getting an hourly text message or a phone call from a fake number pretending to be a government agency, pretending to be a\u00a0telecommunications company or a utility,\" Mr Jones said.", "\"These sorts of things [to combat scammers] have been put in place overseas.\u00a0There's no reason we shouldn't be doing it in Australia.\"", "Mr Jones pointed\u00a0to similar agencies that had\u00a0been established in the United Kingdom and Canada and brought together\u00a0government, banks, investigators and intelligence agencies to tackle fraudsters exploiting the public health crisis by sharing data and tracking criminals in real time.", "", "
Stephen Jones says the government has been too slow to intercept scammers, and social media companies are too lax.(ABC News)
", "But the Shadow Financial Services\u00a0Minister said social media companies also needed to be held accountable because\u00a0they had profited from enabling scammers to advertise on their sites.", "\"I just think it's unconscionable if you've got social media companies who know there's a practice going on that's either dangerous or unlawful\u00a0that they allow it to continue\u00a0and, even worse, make money out of it,\" Mr Jones said.", "\"We'd like to do it by cooperation in the first instance through new codes of practice. Bring them inside the tent by having them involved in the new anti-scam centre.", "He said Labor would also consider law reform to give telecommunications companies more power to intercept and block scammers, if it was\u00a0found the current laws were insufficient.", "", "
Mr Jones says scammers see Australia as a soft target.(ABC News: Giulio Saggin)
", "An inquiry into COVID-related fraud earlier this year heard from several agencies that fraud had increased exponentially through the pandemic.", "But the Department of Home Affairs maintained the increase was only modest, and police and intelligence agencies said much of the rise was unrelated to COVID-19.", "The Australian Federal Police said\u00a0scammers were becoming more advanced and innovative with their techniques, though the pandemic provided a ripe opportunity for exploitation, with many more people turning to online shopping, some for the first time.", "Home Affairs said\u00a0it was developing a new national framework to detect and respond to cybercrime, as well as collaborating with National Australia Bank to develop new counter-fraud measures.", "But Mr Jones said\u00a0the government had\u00a0been too slow to block scammers from vulnerable Australians.", "\"To the extent that they've done anything at all, they treat it as a national security issue, not as something which is affecting mums and dads and small businesses,\" he said.", "\"And frankly, it's just driving people nuts.\""]
